natural problem: Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.)
natural solution: First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.

Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\

{\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.

Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.

So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 1"
and h1 : "f 2 = 2"
and h2 : "f 3 = 6"
and h3 : "f 4 = 24"
and h4 : "f 5 = 120"
and h5 : "f 6 = 720"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 7 \<longrightarrow> f n = n * f (n - 1)"
and h7 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> gcd (f i) (f j) = 1"
shows  "\<exists> N. f N = 72"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
 We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.
 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\
 {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 1 = 1"
and h1 : "f 2 = 2"
and h2 : "f 3 = 6"
and h3 : "f 4 = 24"
and h4 : "f 5 = 120"
and h5 : "f 6 = 720"
and h6 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 7 \<longrightarrow> f n = n * f (n - 1)"
and h7 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> i \<and> i < j \<and> j \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> gcd (f i) (f j) = 1"
shows  "\<exists> N. f N = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: The function $f$ is defined as follows: $f(1) = 1$, $f(2) = 2$, $f(3) = 6$, $f(4) = 24$, $f(5) = 120$, $f(6) = 720$, and for all $n \geq 7$, $f(n) = n * f(n - 1)$. Moreover, for all $i, j$ such that $1 \leq i < j \leq 6$, the greatest common divisor of $f(i)$ and $f(j)$ is 1. Is there a natural number $N$ such that $f(N) = 72$?

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes rel_prime :: "(int * int) set"
and A :: "(int * int) set"
and B :: "int set"
and P :: "(int list) set"
assumes h0 : "rel_prime = {(a,b). gcd a b = 1}"
and h1 : "A = {(a,b). a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> (a,b) \<in> rel_prime}"
and h2 : "B = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "P = {p. length p = 6 \<and> set p = B \<and> (\<forall> i<5. (p!i, p!(i+1)) \<in> A)}"
shows  "card P = 72"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
 We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.
 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\
 {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes rel_prime :: "(int * int) set"
and A :: "(int * int) set"
and B :: "int set"
and P :: "(int list) set"
assumes h0 : "rel_prime = {(a,b). gcd a b = 1}"
and h1 : "A = {(a,b). a \<in> B \<and> b \<in> B \<and> (a,b) \<in> rel_prime}"
and h2 : "B = {1,2,3,4,5,6}"
and h3 : "P = {p. length p = 6 \<and> set p = B \<and> (\<forall> i<5. (p!i, p!(i+1)) \<in> A)}"
shows  "card P = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem:
Let's consider two numbers, a and b, to be relatively prime if their greatest common divisor (gcd) is 1. 

Now, consider a set A which consists of pairs (a, b) where a and b are elements of set B and are relatively prime. The set B consists of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, and 6. 

Finally, consider the set P which consists of lists of length 6, where each list contains exactly the elements of set B, and where each pair of consecutive elements in the list is a member of set A. 

How many such lists are there in set P? The final answer is 72.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
assumes h0 : "let A = {1::int,2,3,4,5,6}; 
                B = {xs. length xs = 6 \<and> set xs = A \<and> distinct xs \<and> (\<forall>i<5. gcd (xs ! i) (xs ! (i+1)) = 1)}"
shows  "card B = 72"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.

theorem
assumes h0 : "let A = {1::int,2,3,4,5,6}; 
                B = {xs. length xs = 6 \<and> set xs = A \<and> distinct xs \<and> (\<forall>i<5. gcd (xs ! i) (xs ! (i+1)) = 1)}"
shows  "card B = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: How many distinct arrangements of the numbers 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 are there such that the greatest common divisor of every two adjacent numbers is 1? The final answer is 72.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int set \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>A. card A = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>a b. a ∈ A \<and> b ∈ A \<and> a ≠ b \<longrightarrow> gcd a b = 1)"
shows  "f {1..6} = 72"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72

 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.

 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.

 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int set \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>A. card A = 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall>a b. a ∈ A \<and> b ∈ A \<and> a ≠ b \<longrightarrow> gcd a b = 1)"
shows  "f {1..6} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Let $f$ be a function that maps a set of integers to an integer. If for any set $A$ of six elements, any two distinct elements $a$ and $b$ in $A$ are coprime (their greatest common divisor is 1), then find the value of $f$ for the set of integers from 1 to 6. The final answer is 72.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and rel_prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. rel_prime x (x+1)"
and h2 : "card {f x |x. f x \<in> {1..6} \<and> (\<forall> y \<in> {1..5}. rel_prime (f y) (f (y+1)))} = 72"
shows  "card {f x |x. f x \<in> {1..6}} = 720"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.)  Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.

 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
and rel_prime :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> bool"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x \<in> {1..6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. rel_prime x (x+1)"
and h2 : "card {f x |x. f x \<in> {1..6} \<and> (\<forall> y \<in> {1..5}. rel_prime (f y) (f (y+1)))} = 72"
shows  "card {f x |x. f x \<in> {1..6}} = 720"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: A function $f$ maps natural numbers to the set {1,2,3,4,5,6}. For every $x$, $x$ and $x + 1$ are relatively prime. The set of $f(x)$, where $f(x)$ ranges over {1,2,3,4,5,6} and for every $y$ in {1,2,3,4,5}, $f(y)$ and $f(y+1)$ are relatively prime, contains 72 elements. What is the number of elements in the set of $f(x)$, where $f(x)$ ranges over {1,2,3,4,5,6}? The final answer is 720.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (if (\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. (\<exists>! j. n j = i) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..5}. gcd (n i) (n (i + 1)) = 1)) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "sum f {n. \<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. \<exists>! j. n j = i} = 72"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.)  So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.

 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "(int \<Rightarrow> int) \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = (if (\<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. (\<exists>! j. n j = i) \<and> (\<forall> i \<in> {1..5}. gcd (n i) (n (i + 1)) = 1)) then 1 else 0)"
shows  "sum f {n. \<forall> i \<in> {1..6}. \<exists>! j. n j = i} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ that assigns to each sequence of integers a value of 1 if the sequence contains each of the numbers from 1 to 6 exactly once and any two consecutive numbers in the sequence are coprime, and 0 otherwise. Find the sum of the values assigned by $f$ to all such sequences. The final answer is 72.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 6 = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> f k = k)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> k l. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < l \<and> l \<le> n \<longrightarrow> gcd (f k) (f l) = 1)"
shows  "card {f n |n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6} = 72"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
 We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.
 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\
 {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f 6 = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> k. 1 \<le> k \<and> k \<le> n \<longrightarrow> f k = k)"
and h2 : "\<forall> n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6 \<longrightarrow> (\<forall> k l. 1 \<le> k \<and> k < l \<and> l \<le> n \<longrightarrow> gcd (f k) (f l) = 1)"
shows  "card {f n |n. 1 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 6} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ defined on the set of natural numbers such that $f(6) = 6$. For all natural numbers $n$ between 1 and 6 inclusive, $f(k) = k$ for all $k$ between 1 and $n$ inclusive. Moreover, for all $n$ between 1 and 6 inclusive, the greatest common divisor of $f(k)$ and $f(l)$ is 1 for all $k$ and $l$ between 1 and $n$ inclusive, where $k$ is less than $l$. How many distinct values does $f$ take on the set $\{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6\}$? The answer is 72.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> P n \<and> y \<in> P n \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> gcd x y = 1"
shows  "card {P n |n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6} = 72"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
 We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.
 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\
 {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and P :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "n = 6"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> P n \<and> y \<in> P n \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> gcd x y = 1"
shows  "card {P n |n. n \<ge> 1 \<and> n \<le> 6} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given a set P(n) of natural numbers associated with a natural number n such that for every pair of different numbers x and y in P(n), the greatest common divisor of x and y is 1. If n is 6, find the number of such sets P(n) for all n between 1 and 6 inclusive. The final answer is 72.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "bij_betw f {1..6} {1..6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. gcd (f n) (f (n+1)) = 1"
shows  "card {f. \<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. gcd (f n) (f (n+1)) = 1} = 72"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.
 We must arrange the six digits in such a way that no two even digits are consecutive.
 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\
 {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} \\ {\color{blue}e} o o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e }\end{align}For any of these four arrangements, there are $3!$ ways to select the three even numbers and $3!$ ways to select the three odd numbers, for a total of $3!
 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "bij_betw f {1..6} {1..6}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. gcd (f n) (f (n+1)) = 1"
shows  "card {f. \<forall> n \<in> {1..5}. gcd (f n) (f (n+1)) = 1} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $f$ that is a bijection between the sets {1,2,3,4,5,6} and {1,2,3,4,5,6}. If for every n in {1,2,3,4,5} the greatest common divisor of $f(n)$ and $f(n+1)$ is 1, find the number of such functions. The final answer is 72.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes R :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "R = {1..6}"
and h1 : "card R = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> n \<in> R. (\<forall> m \<in> R. m \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> coprime n m)"
shows  "card {n \<in> R. (\<exists> m \<in> R. m \<noteq> n \<and> (\<exists> p \<in> R. p \<noteq> m \<and> (\<exists> q \<in> R. q \<noteq> p \<and> (\<exists> r \<in> R. r \<noteq> q \<and> (\<exists> s \<in> R. s \<noteq> r \<and> n = m * 10^5 + p * 10^4 + q * 10^3 + r * 10^2 + s * 10 + n)))))} = 72"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Six-digit integers will be written using each of the digits $1$ through $6$ exactly once per six-digit integer. How many different positive integers can be written such that all pairs of consecutive digits of each integer are relatively prime? (Note: $1$ is relatively prime to all integers.) The final Answer is 72
 ### Proof
 First, we observe that the only pairs of integers from 1 to 6 that fail to be relatively prime are any pair of even integers as well as the pair (3, 6). If we temporarily ignore the pair (3, 6), we can focus only on parity.

 Using $\color{blue}e$ to denote even and $o$ to denote odd, this gives us four different possible arrangements: \begin{align} {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o \\ o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} o {\color{blue}e} \\

 \cdot 3! = 36$ total arrangements.
 Hence, ignoring the issue of (3, 6) adjacencies, we have $36 \cdot 4 = 144$ such numbers.
 Now, we must count the number of the above arrangements that include any (3, 6) adjacencies and subtract them off.
 Let's consider the number of (3, 6) adjacencies in arrangement $(1)$. Suppose that the first digit is 6. Then if the second digit is 3, there are $2! \cdot 2! = 4$ arrangements of the remaining digits.
 So there are 4 arrangements that go 6 3 \_ \_ \_ \_. If instead the third digit is 6, then by similar reasoning, there are 4 arrangements that go \_ 3 6 \_ \_ \_, and 4 arrangements that go \_ \_ 6 3 \_ \_, for a total of 8 arrangements.
 By symmetry, there are also 8 arrangements that include a (3, 6) adjacency when the fifth digit is 6.
 So, there are a total of $4 + 8 + 8 = 20$ arrangements of $(1)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 By symmetry, there are also $20$ arrangements of $(2)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent. Finally, we must count the number of arrangements of $(3)$ that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 From previous reasoning, we see that if the 6 is on an endpoint, there are 4 arrangements with an adjacent 3, and if 6 is in the interior, there are 8 such arrangements.
 Hence, in this case, there are $4 + 8 + 4 = 16$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 Again, by symmetry, there are also $16$ arrangements of $(4)$ with 3 and 6 adjacent. Overall, there are $20 + 20 + 16 + 16 = 72$ arrangements that have 3 and 6 adjacent.
 So, our final answer is $144 - 72 = \boxed{72}$ numbers.
 *)

theorem
fixes R :: "nat set"
assumes h0 : "R = {1..6}"
and h1 : "card R = 6"
and h2 : "\<forall> n \<in> R. (\<forall> m \<in> R. m \<noteq> n \<longrightarrow> coprime n m)"
shows  "card {n \<in> R. (\<exists> m \<in> R. m \<noteq> n \<and> (\<exists> p \<in> R. p \<noteq> m \<and> (\<exists> q \<in> R. q \<noteq> p \<and> (\<exists> r \<in> R. r \<noteq> q \<and> (\<exists> s \<in> R. s \<noteq> r \<and> n = m * 10^5 + p * 10^4 + q * 10^3 + r * 10^2 + s * 10 + n)))))} = 72"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Consider the set R of natural numbers from 1 to 6. Every pair of distinct numbers from this set are coprime (i.e., their greatest common divisor is 1). How many six-digit numbers can be formed such that each digit is a distinct number from the set R and the six-digit number is represented as $m*10^5 + p*10^4 + q*10^3 + r*10^2 + s*10 + n$, where $m, p, q, r, s, n$ are all distinct numbers from the set R? The final answer is 72.
